Title: Tha Ngon Agricultural Development
content:
MAST[R ciiY1

RESTR ICTED

RRP-27 : LAO

'This Report has been prepared
'for the exclusive_use of the Bank'

AS IAN DEVELOPMENT BANK

REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS

PRESIDENT TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS

OF THE

ONA

PROPOSED LOAN AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE

KINGDOM OF LAOS

10 February 1970

 REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE PRESIDENT TO THE

BOARD OF DIRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN AND
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE KINGDOM

OF lAOS

I submit to the Board of Directors for their con-

1.
sideration and decision the following report and recommen-
dations on a proposed loan in an amount in various curren-
cies equivalent to US$973,000 and technical assistance in
an amount in various currencies not exceeding the equiva-
lent of US$275,000 applied for by the Kingdom of Laos for
implementation of the Tha Ngon Agricultural Development
Project.

•	

I. INTRODUCTION

2.
Laos is one of the least economically developed
member countries of the Bank. As a landlocked country
with a lack of both basic infrastructure and sufficient
resources, the development efforts of Laos face significant
constraints. Traditional agriculture based on family
cultivation of small farms provides subsistence living for
close to 80 per cent of the total population which is
estimated at 2.8 million.

Agricultural productivity is very low with paddy

3.
yields averaging only about one ton per hectare. The
current arable area of the country (7 per cent of the total
area) consists mostly of river valleys, which are cultivated
only during the rainy season, remaining unused for lack of
irrigation water during the dry season. Laos imports a
considerable part of her food requirements as well as most
manufactured and industrial goods. Annual imports of rice
are estimated to be close to 50,000 tons. The foreign
trade position of the country has shown a persistent defi-
cit on the current account over the last ten years.

Long-term economic planning and coordinated deve-

4.
lopment is of recent origin in the country. A royal ordi-
nance of March 1969 promulgated the 5-year development
plan for 1969-1974. The plan attaches high priority to the
development of the social, infrastructure and productive
sectors. In the field of agriculture, the development of
intensive irrigation projects with double cropping and the
application of better farming techniques has been emphasized,

 -2-

the aim being to make the country  self-sufficient in rice
and other food and vegetable crops. Emphasis is also placed
on the production of cash crops for export, such as coffee
and tobacco.

The Government in 1965, established the Agricul.

5.
tural Development Organization (ADO) as a joint Lao-USAID
organization to assist in supplying  farm inputs and to
provide marketing facilities and short-term credit to the
farmers. Distribution of better seeds, fertilizer, trac-
tors and water pumps has been undertaken by this organiza-
tion with the result that, in certain localized parts of
the Vientiane Plain, paddy yields have increased from the
current average of one ton to three and more per hectare.

The Government of Laos has already been the re"L-

6.
pient of a technical assistance program from the Bank. An
agreement approved by the Board on October 15, 1968 resul-
ted in the identification of eight irrigation projects with
a total net irrigable area of close to 34,000 hectares in
the Vientiane Plain. These projects, of which Tha Ngon is
one, will use the water of the Nam Ngum and the Mekong
Rivers by pump irrigation. Electric power for these pumps
is to be provided by the Nam Ngum Dam which is scheduled
for completion by early 1972. Among the agricultural
projects identified for development, the Tha Ngon Project
has been accorded the highest priority both by the Govern-
ment and by the technical assistance mission of the Bank
which submitted its study on the "Integrated Agricultural
Development Programme for the Vientiane Plain" in January
1970. Copies of this Report have been circulated to
members for information.

The Vientiane Plain is the most populated and

7.
socially and politically important area of Laos. The Tha
Ngon Project as appraised by the Bank will provide a unique
opportunity to demonstrate to a large number of farmers the
modern farming techniques that may be employed in other
irrigation projects in the Vientiane Plain as well as in
other parts of the country.

8.
project was studied in the Bank and appraised in the field

In response to the Government request, the

 -3-.

on the basis of a revised feasibility report prepared by
the Overseas Technical Cooperation Agency (OTCA) of Japan
in March 1969. In addition, the Bank's consultants'
report on the Vientiane Plain was also taken into conside-
ration. Subsequent to the appraisal of the project, it was
found that, in order to improve the technical soundness
of the project, certain adjustments in the costs envisaged
would be essential and the Government of Laos has requested
from the Bank a loan in an amount of US$973,000.

In view of  the shortage of engineers and other

9.
trained personnel in the country, the Government has also
requested the Bank for a technical assistance grant up to
an amount not exceeding US$275,000 to provide for engi-
neering, supervisory and training services for the execution
of the project during the three-year construction period..

10.
Formal negotiations for the proposed loan and
technical assistance grant were held in Vientiane from 28
January to 5 February 1970. The Government of Laos was
represented by Messrs. Pane Rassavong, Commissioner
General of Plan (as chief of team), Bouaphat Chanthapanya,
Directeur General de l'Economie Nationale, Souvanthong
Phenglamphanh, Directeur du Budget et du Controle, Tiao
Somsavath Vongkoth, Directeur de 1 'Agriculture, Bounphet
Thavonekham, Directeur des Etudes de la Banque de
Development du Laos, Tougeu Lyfoung, Directeur General
de la Justice.

II. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROPOSED FINANCIAL

ASSISTANCE FOR THE PROJECT

11.
assistance are:

The main features of the proposed financial

Recipient	

: The Kingdom of Laos

Executing Agency	

: The Development Agency

for the Vientiane Plain

Total Amount of
Financial Assistance	
Requested	

:	

The equivalent in various
currencies of US$1,248,000

 -4-

(a) Loan from
Special Funds
Resources	

The equivalent in various
currencies of US$973,000

H

(b) Technical
Assistance Grant

Not exceeding the, equiva-
lent of US$275,000.

Purpose

To finance part of the
foreign exchange construction
cost of the Project, includ-
ing assistance in detailed
engineering design, related
field surveys, assisting in
procurement of construction
machinery and equipment,
supervision of construction
work and training of Laotian
counterpart personnel.

Until December 31, 1973

40 years including 10 years
grace period

Semi-annually in equal
installments

l per cent (including
service fee). Payable semi-
annually starting from the
first year

Period of
Ut ilizat ion

Amortization

Repayment of
Pr inc ipal

Interest	

:	

The consulting services are envisaged to start

12.	
in April 1970 and last until May 1973. The cost of this
technical assistance is estimated at up to US$275,000
and can be accommodated within the current Technical
Assistance Budget of the Bank.

	
	
	
	
	
	
	
	
 -5-

III. THE PROJECT

A report entitled "Arpraisal of the Tha Ngon

13.
Agricultural Project in Laos" is attached (Report No.
Lao-AP-l).

The Project involves joint financing and technical

14.
assistance programs by the Government of Japan and the Asian
Development Bank to the Royal Government of Laos. Tha
Ngon is also the first integrated agricultural project in
Laos and as such represents a pioneering effort.

The objective of the Project is to develop for

15.
year-round irrigated farming an area of about 1,000 has.
The construction of flood protection and drainage systems,
irrigation networks, roads, power distribution and trans-
mission lines and the settlement of about 400 farm families
are included in the Project. Total construction costs are
estimated at US$1,957,000 of which US$1,503,000 represents
foreign exchange and US$454,000 equivalent local currency.
In addition to the financial assistance requested from the
Bank (a loan of US$973,000 and technical assistance of
US$275,000), the Government of Laos is expected to receive
on a grant basis US$255,000 of foreign exchange cost and
US$373,000 local currency equivalent contributions from the
Government of Japan. The Laotian Government will contribute
US$60,000 equivalent in local currency toward the construc-
tion cost and up to US$50,000 equivalent in counterpart
contribution for the local cost of the Bank consultants
during the three-year construction period. Assurances of
these contributions have been obtained from the Government.

Execution of the Project will be the responsibility

16.
of the Development Agency for the Vientiane Plain and
interministerial coordination will be effected through
the Technical Committee for Regional Development of the
National Planning Council. The Development Agency will
have its own budget and staff and draft proposals for its
establishment have been submitted to the Cabinet. The
engineering consultants to be provided under the technical
assistance program will be attached to this Agency. All
Government departments and agencies concerned with agri-
cultural development will be represented on the Technical

 •1

Committee and in the Agency itself. A Project Director
delegated by the Development Agency will be immediately
responsible for the executinn of construction works and
the implementation of the development programme in the
Project area. The Government has made commitments to
provide the Project Director with the required number of
field staff and necessary funds.

The Project, as planned, should enable the farmers

17.
to achieve substantial increases in the production of paddy
and other crops. It will assist farmers in adopting im-
proved farming practices, double cropping and the applica-
tion of modern and scientific farm inputs. A pilot demons-
tration farm of about 100 hectares will be established
within the Project area. An implementation program for
the pilot farm has been prepared by OTCA in December 1969
under which the on-farm investment needs of the pilot farm
and the cost of maintaining the required technical personnel
for an initial period of 5 years will be met by the Govern-
ment of Japan. Six technical experts and 12 volunteers
will be provided for agricultural advisory and extension
services for the pilot farm and the Project area. The
entire foreign exchange cost of US$860,000 and the major
part of the local currency cost (US$208,000) of the pilot
farm and initial farm investment will be financed on a grant
basis by the Government of Japan.

A multi-purpose agricultural cooperative (involving

18.
compulsory membership for all the farmers in the area) will
be established to assist in marketing, the provision of
credit facilities and the collection of water charges for
the Project. This will be the first attempt by the Govern-
ment to set up such a farmers association and to collect
water charges. The Government has decided that water
charges, without impairing the incentive of the farmers,
will be collected for all operation and maintenance costs of
the Project. Part of the investment cost will also be
collected after farmers' incomes have risen sufficiently
to justify such collections.

After full settlement, the project will benefit

19.
over 2,000 people (some 400 families). On a farm size of
2 hectares, gross farmers income should amount to approxi-

 -7-

mately US$860 after the fifth year of project implementa-
tion. After full payment for operation and maintenance and
a significant contribution towards anortization, farmers'
income should still be twice the current average income
realized by farmers on traditional 3-hectare farms in the
Vientiane Plain. Training for irrigation construction,
water management and extension will also be provided for
a large number of natinnal counterparts.

The Project is expected to yield annually after

20.
the fifth year of operation 8,300 tons of paddy and close
to 2,000 tons of vegetables, which would currently be
valued at US$560,000. Since the Vientiane Plain is a food
deficit area and is largely supplied by imports, the
Project will result in considerable foreign exchange savings.

For the economic evaluation, all construction and

21.
operating costs and the value added on the agricultural side
were considered. Inspite of the heavy initial investment
costs, the benefit-cost ratio of the project is 1.25 and
0.96 at rates of discount of 8 and 10 per cent, respectively,
with the economic rate of return approximately 9.75 per
cent. In view of the particularly difficult situation of
the country and its urgent need for productive development
these evaluation results although low adequately justify
the Project on economic grounds. The training and demons-
tration aspects of the project which will generate subs-
tantial indirect social and economic benefits in the future
are an additional, and may be even greater, justification.

Laos is in early stage of economic development.

22.
With heavy balance of payments pressures, a weak economic
basis and the fact that its per capita income is one of
the lowest of the ADB  member countries and taking also
into consideration the gestation period of the project, the
proposed financial assistance on the softest possible terms
is, in my opinion, fully justified.

Procurement will be undertaken in accordance with

23.
the arrangements to be made by the Bank regarding eligible
countries for procurement, the advertising procedures in
such countries and the appropriate certification of origin
in accordance with available special funds resources. The
consultants provided under the Technical Assistance Agree-
ment will assist the government in procurement matters.

 I

-8-

IV. LEGAL INSTRUMENTS AND AUTHORITY

The draft Technical Assistance and Loan Agreements

24.
between the Borrower and the Bank and the related Side
Letters are circulated herewith. By provision of Section
1.01 of the draft Loan Agreement, the Bank ? s Special
Operations Loan Regulation dated 6 May 1969 is made part of
the Loan Agreement. Apart from the usual conditions of the
effectiveness of the Loan Agreement provided in Section
8.01 of the said Regulations, the execution and delivery
of the Agreement between the Government of Japan and Laos
concerning the pilot farm is an additional requirement
before the loan becomes effective.

A general "Ordonnance-loi" authorizing the government

25.
to borrow from the Bank for the implementation of the
projects included in its "Plan Cadre" will be submitted to
the approval of the "Bureau Permanent de l'Assemblee Natio-
nale" while the National Assembly is not in session and
prior to the signing of the Loan. The aforementioned
"Ordonnance-loi" and the duly completed loan documents will
be submitted for approval and ratification by the National
Assembly prior to the effective date of the loan.

V. THE ECONOMY

A report entitled "The Economic Report on the
26.
Kingdom of Laos, (Report No. LAO:EC-1) has been circulated
separately.

The Laotian economy continues to comprise a large

27.
non-monetized sector (about 85 per cent) with recent trends
indicating a relatively rapid growth rate of the monetized
part of the economy. The export earnings position of the
country has improved substantially over the past two years,
although the trade deficit remains high. In spite of heavy
balance of payment pressures and persistent budget deficits,
the national currency, mainly through the effort of aid-
giving countries, has maintained a fairly stable value.
The Government is attempting to increase its revenue from
domestic sources and new tax proposals and reforms are
under consideration.

 Agriculture will remain the mainstay of the economy

28.
for a long time to come. Within the frame work of the
national planning efforts and under bilateral aid, serious
attempts are being made to improve farming techniques and
to settle large numbers of refugees in newly-developed
areas. The higher yields recently achieved through the
introduction of better inputs are encouraging. Certain
indications of accelerated development are apparent, but
the continued internal civil strife exerts a heavy pressure
on the limited resources of the country and a threat to
coordinated development activities. In the determined
efforts of the Government to initiate and execute specific
projects, the assistance of the Bank for Tha Ngon will
represent a significant contribution to the development
of the country.

VI. COMPLIANCE WITH ARTICLES OF AGREEMENT

29.
comply with the Articles of Agreement of the Bank.

I am satisfied that the proposed assistance would

VII. RECO1MENDAT IONS

I recommend that the Board approve the proposed

30.
financial assistance in the terms of the following
resolution:

"Approval of financial assistance to the

Kingdom of Laos for the Tha Ngon Agricul-
tural Development Project in an aggregate
amount equivalent to One Million Two
Hundred Forty Eight Thousand United States
Dollars (US$1,248,000) ."

RESOLVED:

That the Bank shall grant:

(i) a loan from its Special Fund
resources to the Kingdom of Laos in an amount
in various currencies equivalent to Nine

 -10•-

Hundred Seventy Three Thousand United
States Dollars (US$973,000) to mature on
November 1, 2009 and to bear interest
(including service fee at the rate of 314
of 1 per cent) at the rate of one and one-
half per cent per annum and to be upon such
other terms and conditions as shall be subs-
tantially in accordance with the terms and
conditions set forth in the form of Special
Operations Loan Agreement between the Kingdom
of Laos and the Bank which has been presented
to this meeting;

(ii) a technical assistance grant to

Laos in an amount not exceeding the equivalent
of Two Hundred Seventy Five Thousand United
States Dollars (US$275,000) and to be upon such
terms and conditions as shall be substantially
in accordance with the terms and conditions
set forth in the form of Technical Assistance
Agreement between the Royal Government of Laos
and the Bank which has been presented to this
meeting.

TAKESHI WATANABE
President

tration farm of about 100 hectares will be established

18.

19.

mately US$860 after the fifth year of project implementa-

21.

tration aspects of the project which will generate subs-
tantial indirect social and economic benefits in the future
are an additional, and may be even greater, justification.

Laos is in early stage of economic development.

22.
With heavy balance of payments pressures, a weak economic
basis and the fact that its per capita income is one of
the lowest of the ADB  member countries and taking also
into consideration the gestation period of the project, the
proposed financial assistance on the softest possible terms
is, in my opinion, fully justified.

Procurement will be undertaken in accordance with

23.
the arrangements to be made by the Bank regarding eligible
countries for procurement, the advertising procedures in
such countries and the appropriate certification of origin
in accordance with available special funds resources. The
consultants provided under the Technical Assistance Agree-
ment will assist the government in procurement matters.

 I

-8-

IV. LEGAL INSTRUMENTS AND AUTHORITY

The draft Technical Assistance and Loan Agreements

24.
between the Borrower and the Bank and the related Side
Letters are circulated herewith. By provision of Section
1.01 of the draft Loan Agreement, the Bank ? s Special
Operations Loan Regulation dated 6 May 1969 is made part of
the Loan Agreement. Apart from the usual conditions of the
effectiveness of the Loan Agreement provided in Section
8.01 of the said Regulations, the execution and delivery
of the Agreement between the Government of Japan and Laos
concerning the pilot farm is an additional requirement
before the loan becomes effective.

A general "Ordonnance-loi" authorizing the government

25.
to borrow from the Bank for the implementation of the
projects included in its "Plan Cadre" will be submitted to
the approval of the "Bureau Permanent de l'Assemblee Natio-
nale" while the National Assembly is not in session and
prior to the signing of the Loan. The aforementioned
"Ordonnance-loi" and the duly completed loan documents will
be submitted for approval and ratification by the National
Assembly prior to the effective date of the loan.

V. THE ECONOMY

A report entitled "The Economic Report on the
26.
Kingdom of Laos, (Report No. LAO:EC-1) has been circulated
separately.

The Laotian economy continues to comprise a large

27.
non-monetized sector (about 85 per cent) with recent trends
indicating a relatively rapid growth rate of the monetized
part of the economy. The export earnings position of the
country has improved substantially over the past two years,
although the trade deficit remains high. In spite of heavy
balance of payment pressures and persistent budget deficits,
the national currency, mainly through the effort of aid-
giving countries, has maintained a fairly stable value.
The Government is attempting to increase its revenue from
domestic sources and new tax proposals and reforms are
under consideration.

 Agriculture will remain the mainstay of the economy

28.
for a long time to come. Within the frame work of the
national planning efforts and under bilateral aid, serious
attempts are being made to improve farming techniques and
to settle large numbers of refugees in newly-developed
areas. The higher yields recently achieved through the
introduction of better inputs are encouraging. Certain
indications of accelerated development are apparent, but
the continued internal civil strife exerts a heavy pressure
on the limited resources of the country and a threat to
coordinated development activities. In the determined
efforts of the Government to initiate and execute specific
projects, the assistance of the Bank for Tha Ngon will
represent a significant contribution to the development
of the country.

VI. COMPLIANCE WITH ARTICLES OF AGREEMENT

29.
comply with the Articles of Agreement of the Bank.

I am satisfied that the proposed assistance would

VII. RECO1MENDAT IONS

I recommend that the Board approve the proposed

30.
financial assistance in the terms of the following
resolution:

"Approval of financial assistance to the

Kingdom of Laos for the Tha Ngon Agricul-
tural Development Project in an aggregate
amount equivalent to One Million Two
Hundred Forty Eight Thousand United States
Dollars (US$1,248,000) ."

RESOLVED:

That the Bank shall grant:

(i) a loan from its Special Fund
resources to the Kingdom of Laos in an amount
in various currencies equivalent to Nine

 -10•-

Hundred Seventy Three Thousand United
States Dollars (US$973,000) to mature on
November 1, 2009 and to bear interest
(including service fee at the rate of 314
of 1 per cent) at the rate of one and one-
half per cent per annum and to be upon such
other terms and conditions as shall be subs-
tantially in accordance with the terms and
conditions set forth in the form of Special
Operations Loan Agreement between the Kingdom
of Laos and the Bank which has been presented
to this meeting;

(ii) a technical assistance grant to

Laos in an amount not exceeding the equivalent
of Two Hundred Seventy Five Thousand United
States Dollars (US$275,000) and to be upon such
terms and conditions as shall be substantially
in accordance with the terms and conditions
set forth in the form of Technical Assistance
Agreement between the Royal Government of Laos
and the Bank which has been presented to this
meeting.

TAKESHI WATANABE
President
author_pages:
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE PRESIDENT TO THE
BOARD OF DIRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN AND
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE KINGDOM
OF lAOS
I submit to the Board of Directors for their con-
1.
sideration and decision the following report and recommen-
dations on a proposed loan in an amount in various curren-
cies equivalent to US$973,000 and technical assistance in
an amount in various currencies not exceeding the equiva-
lent of US$275,000 applied for by the Kingdom of Laos for
implementation of the Tha Ngon Agricultural Development
Project.
•	
I. INTRODUCTION
2.
Laos is one of the least economically developed
member countries of the Bank. As a landlocked country
with a lack of both basic infrastructure and sufficient
resources, the development efforts of Laos face significant
constraints. Traditional agriculture based on family
cultivation of small farms provides subsistence living for
close to 80 per cent of the total population which is
estimated at 2.8 million.
Agricultural productivity is very low with paddy
3.
yields averaging only about one ton per hectare. The
current arable area of the country (7 per cent of the total
area) consists mostly of river valleys, which are cultivated
only during the rainy season, remaining unused for lack of
irrigation water during the dry season. Laos imports a
considerable part of her food requirements as well as most
manufactured and industrial goods. Annual imports of rice
are estimated to be close to 50,000 tons. The foreign
trade position of the country has shown a persistent defi-
cit on the current account over the last ten years.
Long-term economic planning and coordinated deve-
4.
lopment is of recent origin in the country. A royal ordi-
nance of March 1969 promulgated the 5-year development
plan for 1969-1974. The plan attaches high priority to the
development of the social, infrastructure and productive
sectors. In the field of agriculture, the development of
intensive irrigation projects with double cropping and the
application of better farming techniques has been emphasized,
-2-
the aim being to make the country  self-sufficient in rice
and other food and vegetable crops. Emphasis is also placed
on the production of cash crops for export, such as coffee
and tobacco.
The Government in 1965, established the Agricul.
5.
tural Development Organization (ADO) as a joint Lao-USAID
organization to assist in supplying  farm inputs and to
provide marketing facilities and short-term credit to the
farmers. Distribution of better seeds, fertilizer, trac-
tors and water pumps has been undertaken by this organiza-
tion with the result that, in certain localized parts of
the Vientiane Plain, paddy yields have increased from the
current average of one ton to three and more per hectare.
The Government of Laos has already been the re"L-
6.
pient of a technical assistance program from the Bank. An
agreement approved by the Board on October 15, 1968 resul-
ted in the identification of eight irrigation projects with
a total net irrigable area of close to 34,000 hectares in
the Vientiane Plain. These projects, of which Tha Ngon is
one, will use the water of the Nam Ngum and the Mekong
Rivers by pump irrigation. Electric power for these pumps
is to be provided by the Nam Ngum Dam which is scheduled
for completion by early 1972. Among the agricultural
projects identified for development, the Tha Ngon Project
has been accorded the highest priority both by the Govern-
ment and by the technical assistance mission of the Bank
which submitted its study on the "Integrated Agricultural
Development Programme for the Vientiane Plain" in January
1970. Copies of this Report have been circulated to
members for information.
The Vientiane Plain is the most populated and
7.
socially and politically important area of Laos. The Tha
Ngon Project as appraised by the Bank will provide a unique
opportunity to demonstrate to a large number of farmers the
modern farming techniques that may be employed in other
irrigation projects in the Vientiane Plain as well as in
other parts of the country.
8.
project was studied in the Bank and appraised in the field
In response to the Government request, the
